page.name: Aesthetics: viewsheds
page.title: Model coverage and general information
page.description:
Aesthetic values are typically defined as the value derived from views or proximity to open space. These values often accrue to housing or property values and are often measured using hedonic pricing. Park visitors (e.g., hikers) and drivers along scenic highways may also value scenic views, although we consider these values in ARIES using recreation models. Spatial mapping of homeowners is relatively straightforward, as housing units and viewshed values have been frequently analyzed in hedonic studies of amenity values. View values rely on an unimpeded line of sight to visually significant objects such as mountains or water bodies.

Sources of aesthetically valuable views include mountains, water bodies, or specific vegetation types such as forests or riparian areas. Users of aesthetic views are found in residential areas. As a view travels from source to user, it may be physically blocked by buildings, trees, or topography. Its quality may be depleted by air pollution or visual blight, such as highways, forest clearcuts, transmission lines, mines, or visually unappealing land use including commercial, industrial, or transportation. Such sinks, or locations of visual blight, can also be mapped. Higher concentrations of residential users or visual blight lead to higher levels of ecosystem service use or sinks, respectively.
